application_type_full: Prior Approval: Change of use - retail/takeaway to dwellinghouses
description: Partial change of use from Retail (Class A1) to Dwelling (Studio) (Class C3)
decision_conditions: The proposed change of use from retail to residential is considered to fall within the parameters of permitted development as set out under Schedule 2, Part 3, Class M of the Town and Country Planning (General Permitted Development) (England) Order (2015) (as amended).

Officer ReportApplication SiteThe site comprises a detached dwelling located within the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character. The trees on the site are covered by a Tree Protection Order (TPO).Proposal Erection of a single storey garden outbuilding (Retrospective).Consultations7 properties were notified of the proposal. No representations were received.  The key areas of assessment are:- The design of the proposed development; and,- The impact of the development on the amenities of existing and future occupants of land and buildings; and,- The impact of the development on the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character; and,- Protected Trees; and,- Fire SafetyCharacter and AppearanceWhen read together Policies CS8 and DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) require proposals to be of a high quality design that respects the character and appearance of the original building and the prevailing character of the surrounding area. Officer Comment: The proposed development is considered to be acceptable in terms of scale, form, bulk, height, massing, spacing and design. It is considered that there would be no adverse impacts on the character or appearance of the area as a result of the proposed development.The proposed outbuilding due to its siting would not be directly visible within George Road, therefore there would be no significant impact on the existing street scene. Non-Designated Heritage AssetsParagraphs 199 to 208 of the NPPF 2021 set out the method for assessing the impact of development proposals on heritage assets. Policy HC1 of the London Plan 2021 and Policies CS8 and DM12 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 echo these requirements.Paragraph 203 states that the effect of an application on the significance of a non-designated heritage asset should be taken into account in determining any application. In weighing applications that directly or indirectly affect non-designated heritage assets, a balanced judgement is required, having regard to the scale of any harm or loss and the significance of the heritage asset.The application property falls within the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character which is a non-designated heritage asset. As stated above Officers consider that the proposed development would not result in an adverse impact to the host property or the character and appearance of the surrounding area. It follows that Officers consider that the proposed development would  not result in harm to the significance of the Kingston Hill/Coombe Hill Strategic Area of Special Character.Neighbouring AmenitiesPolicy DM10 of the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Local Development Framework Core Strategy (CS)(2012) and the guidance in the Royal Borough of Kingston upon Thames Residential Design Guide SPD (2013) requires proposal to have regard to the amenities of the future occupants of the development as well as those of the existing occupants of neighbouring land and buildings, including in terms of privacy, outlook, sunlight/daylight, avoidance of visual intrusion and noise and disturbance.Officer Comment: It is considered that the proposed development due to its siting and modest scale would not adversely affect the amenities of the occupiers of neighbouring properties by reason of overbearing appearance, loss of light or loss of privacy.Protected TreesPolicy G7 of the London Plan 2021 states that development proposals should ensure that, wherever possible, existing trees of value are retained. If planning permission is granted that necessitates the removal of trees, there should be adequate replacement. Policy DM10 of the Council's Core Strategy 2012 expects new development to ensure that trees that are important to the character of the area or covered by Tree Preservation Orders (TPOs) are not adversely affected.While the retrospective character of the application is acknowledged, the Council's Tree Officer has noted that the applicant planted a substantial landscaping scheme in connection to the applications ref no 22/02105/CLC and 21/00617/HOU, and therefore additional tree planting to mitigate any potential harm is not required in this case.  Fire SafetyLondon Plan Policy D12(A) requires all development proposals to achieve the highest standards of fire safety, embedding these at the earliest possible stage.The applicant has submitted a Planning Fire Safety Strategy, which is considered acceptable. ConclusionIn conclusion, the proposed development is considered to be in accordance with the development plan taken as a whole and there are no other material considerations which warrant a decision other than in accordance with the development plan.

Please confirm the proposal. The application form states: "Erection of porch at the front of the property together with first floor side extension." but the plans only show the proposed front porch. There are no first floor plans provided. Please amend the application form if the proposal is only for the front porch, or provide plans as necessary.
